campaign.story:
City + Theme
The protagonist of HomeMake has always been the city. The game began by trying to represent a continuously changing city that adapts and morphs to each unique user. The design of the city has been in our minds since we were children; a city that is fantastical with a cyberpunk edge. We want it be as sublime as possible, mixing nostalgic suburban landscapes with futuristic urban boroughs.
The city is situated on an inverted sphere, providing an endless playing field without the traditional environmental tropes that stall one’s exploration. Traditional mapping is impossible as the city is always reforming, the only way to unlock the secrets of the city is start an adventure and explore.
City + Location
Cities change every day. In HomeMake the environment will constantly change at an unnoticeable rate.  The concept of progression works on multiple scales. The overall scope of the game is one of progression, as the player evolves their understanding of the world and narrative, the city morphs and adapts, creating an ever changing cityscape. The totality of the system is never fully understood as a constant state of progression is maintained.The game will be set in Galaxy SEED (Stellar Earth Evolution Designer) Sumimoto. The main character lives on the inside of Sumimoto in the suburbs of the city sprawled around the inner surface. An inverted planet, the player travels along the interior surface of the sphere, providing a continuous playing field with no obvious boundaries.
The existence of the urban fabric as an inverted planet creates a variety of unique moments. Although the city development and types of spaces vary widely throughout, the constant factor acting on all structures is the gravity. Radiating from the center, buildings must thrust inward. Available air volume decreases as buildings grow. Negotiations and tensions arise and create architectural problems as buildings begin to bump into each other. The nature of the street, and the views of the city above are in constant dialogue with the battle happening between buildings as they clash in the sky.
The complexity of the views coupled with the sublime understanding of motion and relativity caused by the centralized gravity results in challenging platforming elements as players travel across the city hunting new goals.
City + Identity
Our desires to explore such a city lead to the mind transfer game mechanic. We wanted to understand what it felt like to inhabit our city but not just from our own point of view. Every resident of a city has a unique take on the environment, with their own personal biases and experiences coloring their understanding, a wholly unique version of the same city lives inside everyone’s heads. In exploring our city, we often found ourselves changing our characters attributes to gain a different perspective of our city through a new method of interaction. We want our game to explore these subjective understandings of space and how they related to the individual character.
As a result, Sumimoto is littered with multiple avatars, each with distinctive abilities, desires and biases. This causes multiple body swaps as one traverses the shifting cityscape. This piqued our imagination as we began to speculate on the possibility of multiple perspectives; our city is experienced a lot differently between different avatars. Playing as either a robot, a plant, or a hippo, not only will the city change to match your characters unique abilities, but perceptually the city will be represented in a new way, reflecting each character’s take on the environment.
City + Desire
Gameplay revolves around perceptual based puzzles that require body swapping to unlock the secrets of the city. Different bodies provide different platforming advantages. Some run faster. Some see sound. Some talk smooth. The changing urban fabric encourages the player to swap bodies in order to address the immediate landscape around them.
Regarding to the platforming elements, the constant changing of the city creates an ever expanding series of challenges that arise as geometry shifts and varies. It is at the player’s own discretion that they determine the best character and exploration technique required to advance through the city.
 City + Sound
Our music making experience is rooted in DJing. We want to add this experience of nonstop DJ mixing to the game, providing a continuous soundtrack to compliment the endless environment. As indicated by our opting for an essential mixtape, there will be no set OST for the game, instead different musical parts will blend into an endless tapestry based on environment and gameplay. The musical pieces move through genre from blues to jazz to funk to hip-hop to glitch, creating a hybrid sense of nostalgia and future.
  The Duo
Franklin Cosgrove (Cory) + Archgame (Matt) are architecture students by day and video game designers by night. The city in our game has been building in our minds since we were children in the Midwest, where vast urban fields are still fantasy. Franklin Cosgrove is a comic aficionado and animator, likely found at your local comic book shop every Wednesday. Archgame is a computer programmer and DJ, still preferring analog vinyl control when mixing his music digitally. 
As architecture students, our two man team has extensive experience designing environments and 3D modeling.Our architecture has always been influenced by our experience in the digital environments of video games, now we’d like to reverse this and create a video game that draws on our experience as architects.
Kigi
Kigi is our main robot. Gameplay wise, although he can’t jump very high, he can run fast, see sound, and shoot light. An excellent skill to have when trying to navigate those congested city streets or when you’re in some trouble with the local bullies. He hasn’t always been so functional, however, and your first objective in HomeMake is to sneak out of the house, find all Kigi’s missing parts and piece him together.
Sandwiches
Allow us to introduce Sandwiches the fox. That's right. Sandwiches. Unlike Kigi, Sandwiches, is our most recent addition to the HomeMake cast. The idea came to us when thinking about a character who had to somehow navigate the city using a different sense other than vision. Unfortunately for poor Sandwiches, he is completely color blind, unable to enjoy the poly chromatic city around him. He doesn't seem to mind though as he has a keen sense of smell and a quick pace to make up for it.

Iso
Next, we wanted to introduce you to another one of the main characters, Iso. For the most part, Iso is just a normal kid. You're already seen his pet fox, Sandwiches, and his robotic friend Kigi. Generally speaking, Iso is quite limited in his methods of exploration. He can't run too fast, he's not the best climber, and will therefore have to rely on the abilities of those close to him. Where he excels, however, is in his ability to talk his way out of problems. If you ever need choice information from the inhabitants of Sumimoto, Iso knows how to get it.
Habo
The next character we'd like to introduce is Habo. We show this guy a little bit in the trailer but he is a hint at some of the more dangerous aspects of the city. All places have those spots you don't really want to be at a certain time of day and Sumimoto is no different. He may be a boss but who knows, maybe you'll get to know him first. He could just look scary. I mean, he can't be all bad right?
Check updates for more character bios!

10% Fees
 Many of you have inquired about stretch goals, platforms/consoles and how our Kickstarter success will impact the game's design and distribution. We are more excited than ever about HomeMake's design and encourage everyone to continue sharing this project with as many people as possible.  
We disagree with the idea that there's direct correlation between quality and scope in a project like this. Our original funding goal was the bare minimum and maximum we needed to complete the game as we originally designed it. Recently we've seen a lot of games go beyond their original scope and end up spreading themselves too thin. We have no desire to make the same mistake.
 However, platform/console development does require additional resources outside of the game's original design. The more money we have, the better we can invest ourselves into working on HomeMake unencumbered and release the game to as many platforms/consoles as possible. We are artists first and foremost, so for us it is more important to get HomeMake into as many people's hands as possible over financial success. Currently we hope to release HomeMake on PS3, PS4, Wii, WiiU, and Xbox One, with Sega Dreamcast as a bonus. All extra funds will be put towards as wide a distribution as manageable. We know this seems ambitious, and therefore, we encourage everyone to continue sharing the game and supporting it. This way, we can share HomeMake with as many people as possible!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With no previously published games, we understand we play the underdogs in this story. As architecture students, we have the ability to forego sleep and food to complete projects and meet deadlines but unfortunately pure willpower can only get us so far. Everything in the game is still under development. We are excited to continue honing what we already have and create even more content to give each player a multi-layered environment to explore, but in order to do this, we need your support!

Limited software licenses and old computers have allowed us to bring the game to its current level. With your contribution, we can procure the hardware and software we need to continue working on the game and bring it to its imagined state. The funding will not be going into our mouths or pockets. Every cent will be spent on things absolutely necessary to finish the game or create reward items. This Kickstarter will not only provide us a means of finishing this game, but allow us to continue developing other games in the future.

Currently we plan to release HomeMake for PC, Mac, and Linux, but would love the opportunity to release it for Playstation, Wii, and Dreamcast as well. Made with Unity.

campaign.story:
The Freedom Trail® is a 2.5 mile footpath running through Boston, Massachusetts, that highlights 16 nationally significant historic sites that tell the story of the American Revolution and attracts more than 4 million tourists annually.
Through this book I have engineered and brightly illustrated each of these historic sites so that they pop off the page. The first of its kind, this completely original pop up book includes 16 architecturally accurate pop ups, profiles of each of the five historic weathervanes along the trail and written history about landmarks like The U.S.S. Constitution and the Old South Meeting House.
The time has come to print and publish the book and this is where I need your help!
I plan on self-publishing the book and distributing it through boutiques, bookstores, and gift shops along the trail and throughout Massachusetts. The $52,500 goal will fund a limited run of 5,000 books and cover the cost of printing, production, and shipping. 
U.S.S. Constitution - Charlestown, MA
The Backstory of Boston's First Pop Up Book 
A little over four years ago I traveled to Boston and was excited to walk The Freedom Trail® for the first time.  I became fascinated with Boston’s history, beauty, and the dedication the city has shown in preserving its monuments and landmarks.  Toward the end of my trip I searched for a Freedom Trail® pop up book to bring home to add to my collection of souvenir pop up books.  When I couldn’t find one, I searched for any Boston pop up book.  To my disappointment I found that there were no popup books about Boston at all (only one of Fenway Park, out of print)! So I began to create one.
With encouragement from The Freedom Trail® Foundation and permission to use their medallion and trademark, I developed a succinct written history about the trail and its landmarks and created full color illustrations and architecturally accurate pop ups. The book is truly a one of a kind memento perfect for history lovers, educators, art enthusiasts, and of course, children.
Massachusetts State House - Boston, MA
What's in the book?
There are 16 pop ups in the book as well as a selection of movable pieces and full color illustrations. All painstakingly detailed to echo the architectural splendor of the historically significant buildings of Boston.
They include:
Detail pop ups of a full color rendering of The Freedom Trail® Foundation Medallion and the Frog Pond building on Boston Common
Fully three dimensional, two page pop ups of The Massachusetts State House, Old State House, U.S.S. Constitution, King's Chapel, Old North Church steeple and Faneuil Hall
Old Corner Bookstore Illustration with moveable sign 1717 to 1826
A pop up of my artistic interpretation of Paul Revere's [actually Henry Pelam's] etching of the Boston Massacre 
And more!
What's Next?
If I am funded, I will be able to obtain the final color dummy book from the assembly house. After any edits are completed, the book will go to press. Once printed, the book will be hand assembled, piece by piece, and glued together. When the inside is complete, it will be mounted into the hard cover binding, boxed and shipped to Boston. Then, after the Kickstarter Rewards are sent I will work to distribute and promote the book. With the help of The Freedom Trail® Foundation, their five approved stores for merchandise purchase, the famous Cheers Bar & Restaurant and other local shops that express interest in carrying the book for sale The Freedom Trail® Pop Up book will be available to the public. 
Faneuil Hall - Boston, MA
 We have had some requests to see the weathervane card.  Here it is!  (Of course, your cards won't have the watermark on them :-)
Weathervane Folding Card Sample
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This campaign will fund printing, production, and shipping for a limited run of 5,000 copies of this historic book. 

The greatest challenge for me was engineering and illustrating the book, then sourcing the best place to manufacture it. Now, that is all done and all that is left is the printing. 

But, creating a pop up book is costly! They are all hand produced and assembled and are considered risky investments by traditional publishers at such a small run and limited geographic scope. One of the benefits of crowdfunding this project is that I will be able to make the book available to the general public by removing the risk associated with making one large investment. 

As with all projects, setbacks occur every now and then. I will do my best to send your chosen reward to you at the estimated time, but can't promise it will arrive right on time. If there are delays in production we will promptly inform you.

This book represents four years of research, engineering, illustration, and love and I hope to include you in the publication and success of Boston's first pop-up book!

updates.update_content:
Hello backers!
Today is the official Release Date of the pop up book. I can’t help but be a bit nostalgic as I look back at the last five and a half years. When I started this book I was new to Boston. When I began folding paper to see if I could make it pop up into something that might look like the Old State House, I had been living in Cambridge for six months. In a strange way the creation of the book helped me settle into my new city. Looking back I can’t believe what has happened. How little pieces of folded cardstock grew into a presentation to the Freedom Trail Foundation, to full creation, illustration, working with the individual sites for history that would succinctly fit on their little, folded page to, turndown after turndown from publishers, to funding on Kickstarter, to a trip around the world to see it created to, well...today.

Hello backers,
I am truly thrilled to be able to tell you that the books have, at long last, arrived! Yesterday was full of excitement as the rewards copies were delivered to me.
I am hard at work packing each one up with care and hope to have them all mailed by next week (so keep your eyes on that mailbox!).

Hi everyone,

campaign.story:
*note - The 21st Century Tank Girl book will now be 112 pages long, twelve extra pages have been added thanks to you!
*note - ALL rewards - from £1 upwards - will now come with the illustrated Christmas text-story download "Tank Girl and The Carols" AND the Portable Executive Digital Wallpaper set. ALL physical rewards will now come with the bonus Ashley Wood sticker. ALL Book rewards (signed or unsigned) will now come with the Brett Parson A4 TG Shower-time print. All SIGNED books will come with the Phil Bond A4 Raunchy Booga print AND the Hewlett/Wood jam print AND the "Hewlett & Martin Are Skill" British Library button badge. And ALL pledges for £55 and above will now receive the A2 sized Brian Bolland poster magazine. (see Stretch Goals section, below)
Who or what is Tank Girl?
Tank Girl is a creator-owned comic book series about an Australian outlaw anti-heroine and her friends. The series began in 1988 when Tank Girl appeared in the first issue of Deadline Magazine in the UK. Since then she has starred in her own comics, magazines, a novel, and even her own Hollywood movie (Tank Girl, 1995, starring Lori Petty, Naomi Watts, Ice-T, and Malcolm McDowell).
Tank Girl and Booga by project artist Brett Parson
  I'm Alan, writer of the series, I co-created the character with artist/director Jamie Hewlett. Jamie is now properly world famous as being one half of the team behind the virtual band Gorillaz.
This is my project.
The goal is to create a brand-spanking-new, 100 page, hardback Tank Girl book. It will feature artwork from seven different artists (some Tank Girl veterans and some new chaps), and will be written, edited, and designed by me. 
 This will be a truly independent venture, side-stepping the publishing industry and distribution networks, to deliver a product straight into your hands, direct from the creators.
The confirmed artists on this project are - Jamie Hewlett, Brett Parson, Warwick Johnson-Cadwell, Philip Bond, Jim Mahfood, Craig Knowles, and Jonathan Edwards.
The book will feature two different cover designs, both drawn by Jamie Hewlett - one on the hardcover (case), and one on a wrap-around dust jacket. The latter cover will only be available through this Kickstarter, this will be your one and only chance to buy the book in this form, when the Kickstarter is over, the dust jacket comes off!
 The book will be crammed full with a chaotic mix of short comic strips, poster pages, poems, longer strips, an illustrated text story, and much more. 
You'll discover what Tank Girl's real name is in the story "The Name of Tank Girl" (clue - it's not Rebecca Buck)
You'll learn tactical tank manoeuvres and vital post-apocalyptic survival techniques.
You'll see Tank Girl explore new worlds in her slightly phallic rocket ship.
And you'll finally find out what Tank Girl keeps covered up with that Band-Aid.
The book will be A4 sized (297mm x 210mm), a much larger format than the standard American graphic novel, to better display the fabulous artwork from our crack team of artists.
I'm totally over-excited about the line-up of artists: Jamie hasn't drawn a comic for more than 15 years, and hasn't drawn a Tank Girl strip since 1996! Readers of the original run of comics will recognise the name of Philip Bond, who worked on Tank Girl with us back in the Deadline days, and has gone on to be a regular artist for DC Vertigo. Two recent Tank Girl artists, Jim Mahfood and Warwick Johnson-Cadwell, will return to inject TG with their diverse and radical stylings, and brilliant Brit illustrator Jonathan Edwards will finally get a turn at drawing TG, after originally being slated as artist back in 1996, only to see the Tank Girl publishing empire collapse before he had a chance. The list is topped off with two excellent artists, both new to Tank Girl, who have been setting my blog and the Tank Girl Facebook page ablaze with their incredible artwork - Craig Knowles and Brett Parson (aka Blitzcadet).
Tank Girl by project artist Philip Bond
What is a Kickstarter?
For thirty days, you'll be able to make pledges to help make this project happen, ranging from £1 up to £5,000. 
But we're not just asking you to "donate" your hard-earned cash because we think that we are worthy cause, oh no, we're offering top value-for-money rewards in return for every pledge made.
For your pledge, you can select one of the reward packages—listed to the right—of equal or lesser value to your pledge. You can always pledge more than the minimum required to get a reward if you're feeling generous. Your credit card or other account will not actually be charged at the time you make your pledge, and you can change your mind right up to the final deadline.
If the end of the Kickstarter comes and we've reached our goal, then you all get charged the amount you pledged, and we will get on with writing, drawing, printing, posting, shouting, crying etc. But if we don't meet our goal, then the whole thing is called off. No one gets charged, no fees are applied, everyone keeps their money, and we all go home with no book.
What do I get?
Take a look on the right hand side of this page and you'll see a list of different pledge amounts. Under each amount is a description of the rewards you'll get for that level. 
Most of the levels include either the 21st Century Tank Girl book itself, a smaller comic-style "sampler" of the book (which will have a sampling of content from the book plus some stuff that isn't in the book), or both. These will be shipped when we have finished the artwork and printed the books. We will be using a UK printer, which, while a little more expensive, cuts out the shipping delay that we would get if we printed in the Far East.
Domestic shipping within the UK is included in the price of all reward levels. Some of the shipping costs outside the UK will be absorbed by the pledge level price, but a bit extra is usually required to cover the full expense (worldwide shipping costs are stated at the bottom of each level description).
There's a whole bunch of premium rewards for those of you who really want to step it up, including pieces of original artwork, bespoke text novels, posters, bags of booty, a chance to get killed by Tank Girl in one of the stories, a years worth of gifts and letters, and a book with penises drawn all over it - the perfect gift for the one you love.
Tank Girl by project artist Jim Mahfood
Over-funding and stretch goals
If we're lucky enough to reach our goal and go past it, we've got a lot of plans that we can bring into action. Firstly adding a bit of spit and polish to the book - some spot-varnish, embossing the cover, full-colour end-papers etc. If we exceed that goal, we will hand out some very funny (and a rather naughty) surprise bonus gifts. If we make more than that, we will look into putting funds towards the production of the next-next Tank Girl book!
What will we spend the money on?
Our goal is a big ask, but every penny is accounted for - paying for artwork, lettering, script, printing the books, shipping the books, manufacturing the rewards, handling, packaging, postage, and paying a percentage to Kickstarter and the taxman.
Add-Ons - If you fancy a little extra something...
(please note - Add-Ons are only available with the £23 Book level and higher. No Add-Ons with any Pledge Levels below £23 please!)
Here’s how Add-Ons work - Choose a pledge level from the list on the right, then select any extra items you want to add to your reward from the list below. Follow the payment process until you are asked how much you would like to pay, then simply add the price of your extras onto the price of your pledge level, and that is your total. Remember to make a note of which add-ons you have picked, as you won't be asked what your extra payment is for until the end of the drive! 
Fridge Magnet & Bookmark Set - £2
Badge Set 1 (Tank Girl, Jet Girl & Logo) - £3
Badge Set 2 (Booga, Barney & The Tank) - £3
Postcard Set 1 (Hewlett, Edwards, Knowles, Bond) - £3

The Book (with Magnet & Bookmark) - £25
Jam Bag (see level 13 for contents) - £27
The Book (signed by Alan) (with Magnet & Bookmark) - £30
PLEASE NOTE - Add-ons are only available with Pledge Level 7 (£23 - The Book) and above, due to postage costs. Please DO NOT pledge for a Digital or Sampler level (the £1 to £13 levels) and add lots of stuff on, thinking that you have bypassed any shipping costs - THIS WILL NOT WORK! 
Kickstarter rules stipulate that you can pay for no more than TEN copies of any single item.
The T-Shirt
Especially for this drive, we have unearthed a very special Tank Girl t-shirt design that was a best seller back in the late 80s. A classic TG image by Jamie Hewlett, painstakingly extracted from an old t-shirt, this design will be available in standard unisex style (sizes Small - 3XL) and women's fit (sizes Small - 2XL), and will be screen printed onto a choice of RED, BLACK, NAVY BLUE, or SPORT GREY heavy cotton shirt. It will have a sewn-in TG brand tag, and a card tag hand-sign by Alan. If you choose the t-shirt pledge level, or add a t-shirt to your order as an Add-On, we will contact you after the drive for your choice in size, style and colour.
The old-school Jamie Hewlett designed Kickstarter t-shirt

Risks and challenges
Meeting writing deadlines, facilitating others to meet their artwork deadlines, and fitting in with the print deadline. Designing and organising manufacture of rewards. Logistics of collating, packing and shipping individual rewards...

I am used to doing all of this stuff as an independent creator who has been producing and shipping out merchandise for some years now. 

My experience in the publishing industry has given me useful knowledge of the potential pitfalls and how to avoid them. I have built failsafe timings into the deadlines.

I have formed a limited company with my wife (an experienced retailer and financial planner), specifically for this venture. We have spent the past 6 months planning and refining this project.

About Kooky Creeps:
Kooky Creeps is a limited edition set of four pre-cut ready to assemble papercraft art masks. Designed by paper artist Matt Hawkins, each set comes with all the pieces you'll need to raise from the dead four spooky, kooky characters. Just add glue and your face! More than just an art print this is truly a collaborative art project that you bring to life. Each set will be packaged in a handsomely eerie coffin portfolio, signed and hand numbered by the artist. Kooky Creeps is a limited edition of 1000 sets after that they are gone for eternity. Each mask features an adjustable headband to fit all size of human skulls and a hanger in the back so they can be displayed on the walls of your haunt as well as your face. Each set will be shipped flat to avoid bending and folding.
Meet the CREEPS:
Jack O' Gooblin
Spazmerelda
Kooky Cat
Bonehead
The blood curdling beginnings of Kooky Creeps:
As an artist and papertoy maker I've worked on some amazing projects over the years but there has always been a few ideas that have haunted the back corners of my mind and sketch books that have never seen the light of day. Recently I created a list of 15 dream projects I would like to design and make ranging from a kids pop-up book, to a board game to an 18 hole miniature golf course. One of these projects I thought I could knock off pretty easy to get the ball rolling on my designers bucket list was a set of artisan Halloween masks. What could be more fun than design a set of whimsically weird Halloween masks.  From this Kooky Creeps was hatched. I'd appreciate your support to help me knock-dead this first project on my list.
Kooky Creeps come in a large flat coffin portfollio, signed by the artist and in a hand numbered limited edition of 1000. This is just a mock up, final design may vary.
Why Paper?
Paper is humble, versatile, easy to source and after the fun is all done it is recyclable! I can source and produce these locally. No need to ship over seas from a factory. Not only proudly made in the USA but proudly made just down the street! I love making papercraft projects like this because it creates a collaboration between me and you. This isn't something you buy and put on a shelf your participation is necessary to bring my creations to life and in this case they really come to life when you wear them. 
The root of all evil!
My goal for this project is $6000 this will be enough to help me produce my first run of Kooky Creeps and provide some fun incentives to you the backers. The cost breakdown is approximately this:
$2500 will go towards the printing and die cutting
$2000 will go towards making 2 dies to do the cutting
$250 for the clear bags used for the packaging
$400 for the 13" X 19" stay flat mailers
$850 will go towards the shipping cost of these over-sized mailers
Rewards and Backing levels
At every backing level you will receive a downloadable mini-mask "Wolfmaniac" designed exclusively for Kooky Creeps backers that you can print at home and make. All contributions of any amount are certainly appreciated but the magic number here is $25. At this level and above you will receive a full set of Kooky Creeps when they get produced! Above twenty five we have all kinds of fun stuff added on to the basic mask set so check out the backing levels to the right.
Wolfmaniac, the downloadable pdf mini-mask that comes with all funding levels. Print on your home printer, cut, glue, add string and wear!
Monsterous Thanks
Thanks for taking the time to look over my project and I hope you will help me fuel my passion for fun whimsical papercraft art and get Kooky Creeps up and rolling .

Producing and designing papercraft art is what I do for a living, it's really in my wheelhouse. The only risks I see in this project would be possible delays at press if the printer gets overbooked and backed up. 
And maybe a slight risk of haunting.
